Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, \u00a.proposition: This request is supported by factual allegations set forth below and legal authority under Massachusetts General Laws c. 208, § 28, and related family law precedent.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6,.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court under G.L. c. 215, § 6, as the parties reside in Bristol County.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31..proposition: Plaintiff has consistently acted in good faith to shield the children from harmful circumstances and seeks this modification to ensure their best interests, as defined under G.L. c. 208, § 31.

**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 492 (.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes the court’s duty to prioritize the children’s safety and well-being.
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 492 (.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly articulates that, in custody matters, the governing inquiry is the best interests of the child and directs judges to consider whether the child’s living conditions adversely affect physical, mental, moral, or emotional health. The court then applies that standard by focusing extensively on the child’s needs, harm, stability, and parental behavior affecting the child, which reflects a duty to prioritize the children’s safety and well-being under Massachusetts law.
**Hunter v. Rose**, 463 Mass. 488, 492 (.relevant_excerpt: “Parents have an equal right to custody of their children. … ‘In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is] … what is ‘best for the child’…. The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable… and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

**Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: Parenting time or custody arrangements that expose children to harmful or unsafe conditions must be re-evaluated.
**Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The case concerns a custodial parent’s request to remove children from Massachusetts and sets out the ‘real advantage’ and best‑interests framework for relocation/removal under G.L. c. 208, § 30. While the court discusses comparing conditions in Massachusetts versus South Carolina (schools, housing, services, family connections), it does not hold that existing parenting time or custody arrangements that expose children to harmful or unsafe conditions must be re‑evaluated. The opinion focuses on whether to allow relocation, not on a duty to re‑evaluate custody/parenting time when there are harmful or unsafe conditions, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
**Pizzino v. Miller**, 67 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.”

**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.proposition: The best interests of the children are of paramount importance in custody consideration, as articulated in **Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985).
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal cases the best interests of the children are the paramount concern and frames the statutory “cause shown” requirement as meaning removal must be in the child’s best interests. The court’s discussion of how to balance the interests of the custodial parent, noncustodial parent, and child is grounded in that standard, so the case does support the proposition that the children’s best interests are of paramount importance in custody-related determinations.
**Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas**, 395 Mas.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”}#+#+#+#+#+#+##

**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 184.proposition: Courts may consider the presence of third parties in the home and the impact of their behavior when assessing modifications.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 184.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly indicates that the judge, in assessing whether to modify the existing shared-custody arrangement and permit relocation, considered the impact of conduct by people other than the parents who would be in the children’s household. Specifically, the court notes and affirms the trial judge’s reliance on allegations of misconduct by a step‑sibling in the mother’s home as a factor weighing against increased time in that household. This reflects that the presence and behavior of third parties in the home are part of the best‑interests (and thus modification/removal) analysis.
**Mason v. Coleman**, 447 Mass. 177, 184.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Chelmsford schools were preferable to those of Bristol, particularly for the child with special needs; that uprooting the children would be detrimental to their interests; that the move would cause a reduction of the father’s parenting time that would not be in the children’s interests; **that misconduct allegations against a step-sibling weighed against increased time in the mother’s household**; and that there was insufficient evidence of financial imperative to justify the mother’s move to Bristol.”

**Carey v. Carey**, 44 Mass. App. Ct. 98.proposition: An unsafe or volatile environment endangers emotional and physical well-being, warranting restrictions on parenting time.

**Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812,.proposition: Courts have held that children’s welfare should not be neglected for the sake of parental access without adequate safeguards in place.
**Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812,.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely addresses the tension between maintaining frequent parental contact and protecting the children’s broader welfare in a removal/relocation context. The Appeals Court criticizes the trial judge for focusing too narrowly on preserving weekly visitation and holds that the children’s best interests require considering the custodial parent’s and family unit’s well‑being and alternative visitation arrangements, rather than sacrificing those advantages merely to preserve parental access. This aligns with the proposition that children’s welfare should not be neglected for the sake of parental access without adequate safeguards.
**Hale v. Hale**, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812,.relevant_excerpt: From what we can ascertain, the judge recognized the importance of the "'frequent and continuing contact' of the child with both its parents" ... and entered his judgment prohibiting removal on the basis that the move would make visitation more difficult. We consider that factor not in itself conclusive. The best interests of children for purposes of deciding whether to permit removal are also interwoven with the well being of the custodial parent, and the determination, therefore, requires that the interests of the mother also be taken into account.... The court should not insist that the advantages of the move be sacrificed ... solely to maintain weekly visitation by the father.

**Hickman v. Hickman**, 32 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The nature and impact of the children’s complaints, such as feeling fearful or unsafe, is a significant factor requiring consideration.
**Hickman v. Hickman**, 32 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion in Hickman v. Hickman concerns bankruptcy, lis pendens, and the effect of a probate separate support judgment on a later mortgage foreclosure. It does not discuss children’s complaints, feelings of fear or safety, or how such complaints factor into judicial decision-making. Accordingly, it provides no authority for the proposition that the nature and impact of children’s complaints of fear or feeling unsafe is a significant factor requiring consideration.

**Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540, 54.proposition: Where police involvement at a parent’s residence occurs, this is relevant to determine the safety of parenting conditions.
**Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540, 54.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns statutory interpretation of the Massachusetts paternity statute and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a custodial mother to return to Massachusetts after she has lawfully relocated. It does not discuss police involvement at a parent’s residence, nor does it indicate that such involvement is a factor in assessing the safety of parenting conditions. The cited text focuses on relocation, parental rights, and stability, so using this case for the claimed proposition would be inaccurate.
**Smith v. McDonald**, 458 Mass. 540, 54.relevant_excerpt: "Once it was established that the mother had relocated prior to an adjudication of paternity, the judge had no grounds to examine the reasons for or sincerity of the mother’s move. After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a)...."

**Alberto v. Commonwealth**, 472 Mass. 7.proposition: This Court has the discretion to impose supervised visitation or other protective measures where necessary.
**Alberto v. Commonwealth**, 472 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns interpretation of G. L. c. 276, § 56A and the requirement that a judge determine an adequate factual basis before entering a domestic abuse allegation into the DVRS. It does not address visitation, supervised visitation, or any court discretion over parenting time or similar protective measures. Therefore it cannot be cited as authority for a court’s discretion to impose supervised visitation or other protective measures.
**Alberto v. Commonwealth**, 472 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “We interpret § 56A to mean that before a judge makes a ‘written ruling that abuse is alleged in connection with the charged offense,’ the judge must inquire into and be satisfied that there is an adequate factual basis for the allegations of abuse made by the Commonwealth.”
